sub_title: Assistant Professor, VU Amsterdam| Trained by LSE| Visiting Fellow, LSE, Kings College London, HEA| Chair Convenor, Behavioural Transformations|
summary:
Sanchayan Banerjee is an Assistant Professor (Tenure Track) at Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam. He holds a PhD and MS from the London School of Economics. He is a Fellow of the Higher Education Academy (FHEA), a visiting fellow at the London School of Economics and King’s College London. He is an Associate Editor of Humanities and Social Sciences Communications (Nature) and Behavioural Public Policy (New Voices section). He sits on the Steering Group of the International Behavioural Public Policy Association.

Sanchayan has developed the Nudge+ framework. He uses nudge+ to engage citizens in nudges to promote welfare-improving behaviours, such as low carbon diets, lower food waste, improved vaccine uptake, donations to pro-social charities, et cetera. His research has received more than half-a-million Euros in research funding and grants, till date. He currently leads a 5.7 mn Euro research project on using AI to tailor nudges to facilitate green residential energy investments in the NL. 

His work has been published or is forthcoming in leading peer-reviewed journals, including Nature Sustainability,  Behavioral and Brain Sciences, and Behavioural Public Policy. Sanchayan regularly interacts with different stakeholders to help them improve their sustainability practices such as Scotland Zero Waste, Fife Council, Live Nation Entertainment, Danish Energy Agency, DG Cities, among others.

projects.title: The effect of Information and Commitment in Lowering Meat Consumption: Evidence from a Natural Field Experiment
projects.description:
This paper makes a novel attempt at understanding the effect of nudge plus in influencing the dietary choices of individuals,
primarily residents of Western First-World countries. It undertakes a natural field-experiment with an unchanged subject pool at LSE Bankside, and analyzes the impact of information and commitment in sustainably altering meal choices of subjects. This study is the first of its kind that focuses on lowering meat consumption specifically by incorporating a behavioural change amongst the subjects, and assessing their (real) dietary choices. It relies on predictions of a strong behavioural model of impure altruism, Rational Moral-Choice Model, to evaluate the persuasion rate of information nudge and commitment-device at 11% and 8%, respectively. The nudge plus is effective on 87% of the sample, while it has a boomerang effect on the remaining 13% as suggested by the cluster-analysis based on the Bayesian Belief Updating theory. The findings of this paper are critical in understanding how behavioural policies can be made to induce pro- environmental behaviour amongst individuals. Although the results have to be verified in a bigger sample-setting, this demand led solution offers a unique way to tackle the ongoing climate-change and food security problem.

projects.title: The causal effect of PM2.5, NO2 and O3 on asthma rates in England
projects.description: It makes a novel attempt to evaluate the causal effect of basic single and mixed grade pollutants on the asthma rates in England using sparse (publicly available on INHALE database of NHS) data, and spatial models. Ozone, as opposed to previous studies is found to have strong positive effect on asthma rates, while PM2.5 has a standard effect. NO2 has been shown to have almost no effect.

contributors.headline: Assistant Professor, VU Amsterdam| Trained by LSE| Visiting Fellow, LSE, Kings College London, HEA| Chair Convenor, Behavioural Transformations|

projects.title: A critique of the Social Cost Benefit Analysis of Delhi Metro
projects.description: A report written criticising the techniques of CBA used in the evaluation of costs and benefits of the Delhi Metro report produced by Murthy, et al., (2004). The report analyses the missing components, and the biases in this report. It makes a strong judgement as to why these biases might have arisen, and attributes them to the limited technical know-how at that period. It also conducts a scorecard analysis, and finds that the SCBA report has a low score in both the scorecards. Delhi Metro SCBA reported inflated revenues, fuel savings, and lower than real congestion costs thereby leading to an upward bias in the benefits. It failed to account for cost of fatalities, air pollution, household displacements, sewage treatment, landscape changes, noise and diverted tourism. Thus, social benefits had a downward bias. While the SCBA indicated a social return of 22.7%, this analysis shows that returns were dampened, and must be less than the estimated figures provided by SCBA.
